questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient presented with a 4X3 cm lump in the right upper outer quadrant, with no axillary lymph node involvement. Mammography revealed BIRADS 4b staging. She underwent breast conservation surgery, and the final HPE report showed high nuclear-grade DCIS with necrosis and 10 mm margin clearance. What is the further management?

options.label: A
options.text: Follow up after six months and after that two years.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Adjuvant RT BCS is done for early invasive breast carcinoma (Stage I, IIA, and IIB). After BCS, radiotherapy is given. In this case, high-grade DCIS is present. So radiotherapy is given after BCS . Trastuzumab is given if Her 2 Neu is positive.

Highyeild:

Treatment of breast cancer Early invasive breast cancer (Stage I, IIA, IIB) can be treated with mastectomy or breast-conserving surgery (BCS) along with axillary lymph node (LN) status assessment and radiation therapy (RT). Adjuvant chemotherapy is indicated in case of LN positivity, tumor size larger than 1 cm, or adverse prognostic factors like a blood vessel or lymph vessel invasion, high nuclear or histologic grade, or Her-2-neu overexpression in LN negative tumors larger than 0.5 cm. Neoadjuvant chemotherapy, mastectomy, and adjuvant RT are recommended for Stage IIIA with N1 patients who respond well to neoadjuvant chemotherapy. Systemic chemotherapy and radiotherapy are necessary for grossly involved internal mammary nodes (N3b) . Hormonal therapy is preferred over cytotoxic therapy for patients with distant metastases (Stage IV) who have hormone receptor-positive (ER/PR positive) tumors, bone or soft tissue metastases only, or limited or asymptomatic visceral metastases. Systemic chemotherapy is recommended for patients with hormone receptor-negative tumors , hormone-refractory tumors after three endocrine regimens, or symptomatic visceral metastases . Local, regional recurrence can be treated with resection of the repeat with reconstruction, chemotherapy, hormonal therapy, and RT if not previously received for those who had a mastectomy or with mastectomy, chemotherapy, and hormonal therapy for those with lumpectomy.

questions.text: Insufflation of the abdomen during laparoscopy is done with the help of the following instrument. Name the instrument?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Veress needle The instrument shown in the image is the Veress needle used to insufflate the abdomen during direct puncture laparoscopy Parts of Veres's needle Procedure of direct puncture laparoscopy First, the abdominal wall is grasped with towel clips or fingers to elevate the abdominal wall away from the underlying structures. Then a small incision is made at the umbilicus, and insufflation is done with a Veress needle. The umbilicus is the preferred location for introducing a Veress needle because the abdominal wall is thin at this location. While introducing the Veress needle, two distinct pops can be felt as the needle pierces the abdominal wall fascia and the peritoneum

questions.text: A patient who had undergone cholecystectomy three days back presented with abdominal pain. The patient has tachycardia. WBC count is 11000 cells/mm3, and USG shows a collection of 5x5 cm in the right subhepatic space. What is the next step?

options.label: A
options.text: Pigtail catheter drainage under USG guidance

options.label: D
options.text: Give antibiotics and send the patient home

questions.correct_answer: A. Pigtail catheter drainage under USG guidance
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pigtail catheter drainage under USG guidance The given clinical presentations are suggestive of bile duct injury following cholecystectomy. If USG shows collection following cholecystectomy, the next step in management includes: Drainage of the fluid collection under radiological guidance (Pigtail insertion and drainage) Administration of broad spectrum of antibiotics Strasberg classification of bile duct injury Type A – Bile leak from the cystic duct or minor hepatic ducts Type B – Occlusion of the- biliary tree with no leak Type C – Bile leak from right aberrant hepatic ducts Type D – Bile leak from main bile duct Type E Type E1 – Injury more than 2 cm from the confluence Type E2 – Injury less than 2 cm from the confluence Type E3 – Injury at the confluence Type E4 – Destruction of the confluence Type E5 – Injury to the main bile duct and the aberrant right hepatic duct Goals in the therapy of iatrogenic bile duct injury Control of infection, limiting inflammation Parenteral antibiotics Percutaneous drainage of periportal fluid collection Clear and thorough delineation of entire biliary anatomy MRCP or PTC ERCP (especially if cystic duct leak is suspected) Reestablishment of biliary enteric continuity Tension-free mucosa to mucosa anastomosis Roux en Y hepaticojejunostomy Long-term trans anastomotic stents if bifurcation or higher is involved

Table:

#MANTRA Bile duct injuries The rate of bile duct injury during open cholecystectomy is low (0.1-0.2%), while it is higher during laparoscopic cholecystectomy (0.3-0.85%). Bile duct injury can be caused by acute or chronic inflammation, obesity, anatomic variation, bleeding, acute cholecystitis, pancreatitis, cholangitis, and obstructive jaundice . Inadequate surgical technique and failure to identify structures before ligating or dividing them are common causes of significant biliary injury. Intraoperative cholangiography may help limit the extent of bile duct injury but does not prevent it. Symptoms of bile duct injury may include jaundice with or without abdominal pain. Major ductal injuries are often recognized intraoperatively due to bile leakage, abnormal cholangiogram, or late anatomy recognition. Patients may present with cholangitis or cirrhosis months or years after prior surgery due to a biliary tract injury. Diagnosis of bile duct injury involves imaging studies like USG or CT . The patient should be stabilized with immediate parenteral antibiotics, image-guided percutaneous drainage of fluid collections , and Cholangiography done to identify the level and nature of the injury. Postoperative biliary strictures are best diagnosed with PTC , while ERCP is useful for patients with bile duct continuity who require urgent cholangiography and biliary decompression. CT arteriography is useful in preoperatively evaluating patients with benign biliary strictures to detect unrecognized injury to the hepatic artery or a portal vein branch. In patients presenting with late strictures with evidence of liver dysfunction, a CT arteriogram should be performed to evaluate for evidence of portal hypertension.

questions.text: A patient presented with abdominal pain. On USG, multiple gallstones were noted, and CBD diameter is 12mm, and no gallbladder wall thickening was seen. Laboratory investigations showed serum Bilirubin of 0.8mg/dl, alkaline phosphatase is 380 IU/L, and GGT is 5 times normal. What will be the next step of management?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

MRCP In the given case, a CBD diameter of 12mm and ALP levels of 380 IU/L, and five times rise in the GGT indicate CBD stones. So MRCP(Magnetic resonance Cholangiopancreatography) is done to confirm the presence of CBD stones. ERCP is both diagnostic and therapeutic but associated with complications. So, on MRCP, if CBD stones are present, then ERCP is done to remove CBD stones. MRCP is highly sensitive (>90%), and specificity is almost 100% for diagnosing CBD stones. It is non-invasive.

Highyeild:

MRCP is a susceptible and specific diagnostic tool in detecting CBD stones. Sensitivity and specificity rates of MRCP exceed 90% and 99% , respectively. MRCP is a non-invasive test and cannot be used to treat CBD stones. Additional procedures such as ERCP or CBD exploration may be required following diagnosis. Preoperative MRCP can be used to determine whether preoperative ERCP is necessary.

Table:

#MANTRA The widespread availability of ultrasound and MRCP has reduced its diagnostic use. However, ERCP still has an important role in assessing the patient with obstructive jaundice to determine the obstruction's cause and level. Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography (PTC) is an invasive technique useful in studying anatomy and biliary strictures. Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography (PTC) is rarely needed in patients with common bile duct stones but can be performed for diagnostic and therapeutic reasons in patients with contraindications to endoscopic or surgical approaches. Transabdominal ultrasonography (US) is the initial imaging modality for gallstones.

Sestamibi scan The clinical features of kidney stones, abdominal cramps, painful bones, and psychosis indicates the diagnosis of primary hyperparathyroidism Classic pentad of primary hyperparathyroidism Kidney stones Painful bones Abdominal groans Psychic moans Fatigue overtones Most common cause of primary hyperparathyroidism is parathyroid adenoma. The best investigation to diagnose the primary hyperparathyroidism due to parathyroid adenoma is the Sestamibi scan.

questions.text: What is the angle of needle placement in suturing a laceration by interrupted suture technique?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

90 degrees The needle should be placed at 90 degrees (right angle) for interrupted sutures

Highyeild:

Interrupted sutures Interrupted sutures require the needle to be inserted at right angles to the incision and then to pass through both aspects of the suture line and exit again at right angles The needle needs to be rotated through the tissues rather than to be dragged through for fear of enlarging the needle hole. As a guide, the distance from the point of the needle to the edge of the wound should be approximately the same as the depth of the tissue being sutured. Each successive suture should be placed at twice this distance apart Each suture should reach into the depths of the wound and be placed at right angles to the axis of the wound. In linear wounds, it is sometimes easier to insert the middle suture first and then to complete the closure by successively inserting sutures, halving the remaining defects in the wound length Interrupted suture technique. Reproduced with permission from the Royal College of Surgeons of England. (b) The siting of sutures. As a rule of thumb, the distance of insertion from the edge of the wound should correspond to the thickness of the tissue being sutured (x). Each successive suture should be placed at twice this distance apart (2x).

questions.text: A 17 years old male presented to the hospital with recurrent attacks of intussusception. Multiple polyps were found during surgery. One of the polyps was removed and sent for histopathological examination. The HPE image is given below. Identify the pathology?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hamartomatous polyp The image given shows arborizing (Tree-like pattern), which is characteristic of the hamartomatous polyp seen in Peutz-Jeghers syndrome. Peutz Jeghers syndrome Autosomal dominant Polyps are more common in the small intestine (most common in Jejunum) Gene – LKB 1 / STK 11 (Chr. 19) Other features – Hyperpigmented melanotic macules, recurrent attacks of intussusception

Table:

#MANTRA Non-neoplastic polyps of the large intestine Hyperplastic Polyps Most common type of colorectal polyp , accounting for over 90% of cases. Typically found in the rectosigmoid area and have a serrated, saw-toothed appearance. No risk of developing cancer. Hamartomatous Polyps Localized overgrowth of normal, mature intestinal epithelial cells. Usually lined with normal epithelium over a submucosal core. Juvenile polyps are the most common type of colorectal hamartomas and often occur in children under 5. Symptoms include rectal bleeding, mucus discharge, diarrhea, and abdominal pain. Also known as retention polyps due to the inflammatory obstruction of the crypt necks leading to cystic dilation of the mucus-filled glands. No increased risk of cancer. Peutz-Jegher’s Syndrome (AD) Characterized by hamartomatous polyps with arborization and pseudoinvasion. Inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. Inflammatory Polyps More commonly found in chronic ulcerative colitis , but can also occur in Crohn’s disease . No malignant potential and typically requires no treatment other than that of the underlying condition.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the hospital by his mother as she notices a huge abdominal swelling. She also gave the history of blood in the child's urine two days back. On examination, the swelling is ballotable. Which of the investigations can be done to confirm the diagnosis? CECT PET CT Urine VMA levels FNAC Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

a only The clinical features of hematuria and ballotable abdominal mass in the three years child suggest Wilms’ tumor (nephroblastoma). CECT or MRI of the abdomen is used to identify the extent of disease, to access other kidneys and metastasis - used in the staging of disease Other investigations: USG (origin and nature), CT chest (detect metastasis)

Highyeild:

Nephroblastoma (Wilms’ tumor) This is the most common tumor in childhood, accounting for 5% of all childhood cancers. They are bilateral in 5% of cases and familial in 1%. Pathology : The tumor has mixed elements derived from the embryonic nephrogenic tissue, namely blastemal or undifferentiated tissue, epithelial tubules, and stroma. Presentation : The typical presentation is a child aged between 1 and 4 years of either gender with a large, palpable abdominal mass that may cross the midline. It may also be associated with haematuria, hypertension, fever, and weight loss. Pain is relatively uncommon. The large tumor can rupture and present as an acute abdomen. Differential Diagnosis : Other causes of renal masses include neuroblastoma, congenital mesoblastic nephroma, RCC, clear-cell sarcoma, and rhabdoid tumor. Investigations : The US can confirm the mass's renal origin and solid nature. Further definitive imaging with either CECT or MRI is necessary to stage the disease. Up to 13% of patients have bilateral tumors. The tumors usually infiltrate the kidneys, and normal renal parenchyma is compressed at the periphery around the tumor (claw sign) . ACT of the chest should be obtained as the lung is the most common site of distant metastasis. Treatment : Current treatment is nephrectomy with pre- or postoperative chemotherapy. Both regimes have a comparable survival of ~90%.

Extraedge:

A mutation in the Wilms’ tumor suppressor gene (WT1) causes some cases Survival depends on tumor spread, completeness of excision, and histological appearance but exceeds 70% even with advanced tumors

questions.text: A 26-year-old male patient presented with significant swelling in the right scrotum and a dragging sensation. On examination, the node is painless, round, firm, and testicular in origin. The left testis is normal. On investigation, AFP is 3000U. What is the next best step in the management?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

High inguinal orchidectomy The clinical features of a large, round, firm, and painless mass of testis and raised AFP levels (3000) are suggestive of Non-Seminomatous Germ Cell Tumor (NSGCT) of the testis. In this case, USG should be done in this case, which shows an enlarged testis with hypoechoic areas. The involvement of other testis and the presence of secondary hydrocoele can be seen on ultrasound. High inguinal orchidectomy is done after USG, but as USG is not given in the options, the next best step is High inguinal orchidectomy.

Highyeild:

Testis tumor staging and treatment Tumour markers (AFP, HCG, and LDH) help to make the diagnosis and to follow the response to treatment CT scanning of chest, abdomen, and pelvis is central to the staging of testicular tumors Testicular tumors are susceptible to platinum-based chemotherapy Prognosis is excellent when the patient is treated with combination chemotherapy in a cancer center Management of NSGCT Up to 50% of patients with NSGCT with CSI disease have subclinical metastases and will relapse during surveillance. Surveillance : 14–48% of CSI-NSGCT patients undergoing surveillance have a recurrence within two years of orchidectomy. Careful surveillance can be an option for compliant, risk-stratified (based on the presence of lymphovascular invasion) patients who are well-informed about the expected recurrence rate and the salvage treatment. Adjuvant chemotherapy : One cycle of bleomycin–etoposide– cisplatin (BEP) is now the recommended strategy with recurrence rates of around 3%. The very long-term side effects, particularly cardiovascular, remain to be ascertained. Retroperitoneal lymph node dissection (RPLND) : The role of this surgery has now decreased with 2-year recurrence-free survival with adjuvant BEP × 1 versus RPLND favoring chemotherapy with a recurrence-free survival of 99.5% versus 91%.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- FNAC (Option A) and Biopsy (Option C) are contraindicated in testicular tumors because they can cause needle track seeding.

Extraedge:

The halflife of β-human chorionic gonadotropin is 24 to 36 hours, and the half-life of α-fetoprotein is 5 to 7 days; these levels should normalize in the absence of metastatic disease

questions.text: Identify the urinary crystals shown below:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Triple phosphate stones The given image shows coffin lid shape seen in Struvite(Triple Phosphate stones). They form as a result of urease-producing bacterial infections, such as those caused by Proteus, Klebsiella, Serratia or Enterobacter. Alkalinisation of urine takes place as urease hydrolyses urea to carbon dioxide and ammonium

Highyeild:

Urolithiasis Epidemiology Modifiable Factors: Age Gender Ethnic Origin Family History Non-Modifiable Factors: Environmental Factors Drugs Pathogenesis: When the concentration of culprit salts such as calcium and oxalate overwhelm inhibitory factors (e.g., citrate, potassium, magnesium, Tamm–Horsfall mucoproteins, pH changes), they precipitate into crystals. These crystal nuclei may be washed off with the flow of urine or they may anchor onto sites like renal papillae to form Randall’s plaques. Variations in the pH of urine may also facilitate or inhibit stone growth; acidic pH precipitates the formation of uric acid stones and alkaline pH precipitates the formation of calcium phosphate stones. Hence, the manipulation of pH through medication can help in preventing new stone formation Milk Of Calcium Stones: Stasis of urine also promotes stone formation. questions.text: A boy is brought to the emergency room after he fell from his bicycle. His vitals are stable and bruising over the perineum is seen. The boy has not passed the urine yet. Blood is seen at the meatus and the bladder is not palpable. What is the management?

options.label: D
options.text: Wait for the bladder to fill and urge to urinate

questions.correct_answer: D. Wait for the bladder to fill and urge to urinate
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Wait for the bladder to fill and urge to urinate The clinical features of Perineal bruise and blood at the meatus after fall from bicycle suggests bulbar urethral injury. As the bladder is not palpable, we have to wait for the bladder to fill and urge to urinate. Once the bladder is full, the suprapubic catheterization is done and the urine is drained. Delayed anastomotic urethroplasty after 8 – 12 weeks is the preferred definitive management.
